content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Claire Romero: I was born in the United States, in a small town in New England, and I've lived in Newton, Massachusetts, since I was sixteen. My parents were both graduates, and they valued education a lot. My father was a teacher, and my mother worked as a nurse. We had a pretty average income, but it was enough to give me and my siblings a stable childhood. I remember growing up in a close-knit family, with both parents always encouraging us to pursue our dreams. I was a quiet kid, more into books than sports, and I always knew I wanted to go to college. I ended up earning a bachelor's degree in psychology, which led me to a career in human resources. Life hasn't always been easy—my marriage didn't last, and I've had my share of challenges, but I've always tried to stay positive and focused on what matters most.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Claire Romero: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped the course of my life. I was in my junior year of college, studying psychology, and I had the opportunity to intern at a local nonprofit that provided counseling services to underserved communities. At the time, I was torn between pursuing a more traditional career path, like becoming a therapist or counselor, or going into something more business-oriented, like human resources. I had always been interested in people and how they interact, but I wasn't sure if I wanted to work directly with individuals or in a more organizational role. I decided to take the internship, and it was there that I realized I was more passionate about the systems and structures that support people rather than working one-on-one with them. That experience led me to switch my focus to organizational psychology and eventually to a career in human resources. It was a pivotal decision because it aligned my interests with my strengths and gave me a sense of purpose that I hadn't felt before.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Claire Romero: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made all at once. It was more of a realization that unfolded over time. I had always been drawn to understanding people and how they functioned within groups, but I didn't fully grasp how that could translate into a career until that internship. I remember sitting in my dorm room one night, staring at my notes, and thinking, 'What if I could help shape the environments where people thrive, instead of just helping individuals one at a time?' That moment was the catalyst. I made a list of pros and cons, talked it over with my advisor, and then committed to the path. It wasn't just about making a decision—it was about aligning my values with my work, and that felt like a choice I had to make deliberately.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Claire Romero: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk through those decisions with made all the difference. My advisor at the time, Dr. Bennett, was incredibly supportive. He didn't push me toward any specific path, but he asked the right questions that made me reflect more deeply on what I truly wanted. Also, my mother, who had always worked in healthcare, gave me a different perspective. She told me about the challenges of working directly with patients and how important it was to have systems in place to support them. Her experience helped me see that I didn't have to choose between helping people and working in a more structured environment. I think both the people in my life and the organizations I was exposed to played a role in guiding me to the right decision, even if I was the one who had to take the first step.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Claire Romero: I'm currently divorced, and while I'm not in a romantic relationship right now, I have a strong bond with my two adult children, who are both living their own lives. My son, Marco, is a software engineer in Boston, and my daughter, Elena, works in public relations in New York. They both stayed in touch with me throughout their upbringing, even though my divorce was a tough time for our family. I try to be involved in their lives as much as possible, whether it's through phone calls, video chats, or visiting when I can. I also have a close relationship with my parents, who still live in the same small town in New England where I was born. They're both retired now, and we get together for holidays and family gatherings. I think family is the foundation of who I am, and even though my life has taken some unexpected turns, I'm grateful for the relationships that have stood the test of time.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by the people and experiences that have guided me along the way. From my childhood in Newton, where my parents instilled in me the value of education and hard work, to the pivotal internship that helped me realize my passion for organizational psychology, each step has led me to where I am today. It's interesting to reflect on how my decision to pursue human resources wasn't just a sudden choice, but a gradual realization that aligned with my values and strengths. I'm grateful for the support of my advisor, Dr. Bennett, and my mother, who helped me see the bigger picture. Even though my marriage didn't last, I'm proud of the relationships I've built with my children and my parents, who continue to be a source of love and stability in my life. These interviews made me appreciate how much my journey has been about growth, connection, and staying true to myself.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Claire Romero: My brother, Antonio, lives in Florida and works as a real estate agent. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but we keep in touch through messages and occasional visits. He's always been more of a free spirit than I am, and I think that's why we sometimes have different perspectives on life. Still, I admire his ability to take risks and follow his passions. Our relationship has its ups and downs, but I know he's always had my back, especially during my divorce. He even flew up to Newton for a few days to help me move out of the house, which meant a lot. I think family is about showing up, even when things get complicated, and I'm grateful for the bond we've maintained despite our differences.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Claire Romero: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who I met in college. We were in the same psychology class, and we bonded over our shared interest in human behavior. She went on to become a social worker, and even though our careers took us in different directions, we've remained close. She's someone I can talk to about anything, and she's always been a source of support, especially during my divorce. Then there's my coworker, James, who I've known for over a decade. He's been a great mentor in my career, and we often grab coffee or lunch to catch up. He's helped me navigate the challenges of working in human resources, and I really value his perspective. I think having people in your life who understand you and are there for you, even when things get tough, is really important. Those relationships have helped me stay grounded and focused on what matters most.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Claire Romero: I live in a quiet neighborhood on Chestnut Hill Ave in Newton, which has a really tight-knit community feel. It's one of those places where you know your neighbors, and people look out for each other. The streets are lined with old, beautiful homes, many of which have been around for generations. I love walking around the area, especially in the fall when the leaves change colors and the air is crisp. There's a local park nearby where I like to take my dog for walks, and it's a great spot for people-watching. The town has a mix of families, professionals, and retirees, which gives it a nice balance of energy and calm. I've lived here for a while now, and even though I've had my share of life changes, this neighborhood has remained a constant. It's a place where I feel grounded, and I appreciate the sense of stability it provides.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Claire Romero: I definitely feel safe here. Newton has a strong sense of community, and I've never felt threatened or uneasy in my neighborhood. There's a kind of quiet confidence that comes with living in a place where people know each other and look out for one another. I've walked alone at night, taken my kids to school without hesitation, and even left my door unlocked when I was home alone—though I don't recommend that anymore, just saying. It's not just the physical safety, though; it's the emotional safety too. I know if something were wrong, someone would be there to help. That sense of security is something I really appreciate, especially after going through my divorce and all the changes that came with it. This neighborhood has been a constant in my life, and I'm grateful for that.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Claire Romero: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, the sense of community is something I truly value. I've made friends with neighbors over the years—some I've known for decades, others I've met through local events or the park. There's a real sense of belonging here, and I think that's why I've stayed rooted in this area even through life's changes. That said, there are moments when the quiet can feel a bit isolating, especially after a long day at work or during times when I'm going through something personal. I've learned to balance that by getting involved in community activities, like the local library's book club or the annual neighborhood potluck. It helps me stay connected and reminds me that even in a small town, there's always something happening if you're willing to look for it.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10 made me reflect on how much my family and neighborhood have been constants in my life, especially during times of change. Talking about my children, my parents, and my brother reminded me of the strength and support that family provides, even when relationships aren't perfect. It also made me appreciate how much my neighborhood has been a source of stability and safety for me. Living in Newton has given me a sense of belonging, and even though there are moments when the quiet can feel isolating, the community spirit here has always pulled me back in. I think it's important to have both strong family ties and a supportive environment, and I'm grateful for both in my life.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Claire Romero: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though I try to keep some flexibility. I work full time in human resources at a mid-sized tech company, so Mondays through Fridays are pretty much the same—early mornings, meetings, employee check-ins, and a lot of behind-the-scenes work that keeps the workplace running smoothly. I usually start my day with a cup of coffee and a quick walk around the neighborhood before heading into the office. On weekends, I like to spend time with my kids, especially if they're in town. We often have family dinners or go out for a movie or a walk in the park. I also try to set aside some time for myself, whether it's reading, doing a puzzle, or just sitting on the porch and watching the world go by. I've found that having a routine helps me stay grounded, but I also make sure to leave room for spontaneity—like when my brother surprises me with a visit or when the neighborhood potluck happens. Life is full of little moments, and I try to savor them as much as I can.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Claire Romero: I work full time in human resources at a mid-sized tech company in Cambridge, just a short commute from Newton. My job is pretty varied—some days I'm handling employee onboarding, others I'm mediating conflicts or working on diversity and inclusion initiatives. I typically start my workday around 8:30 a.m., though I like to get in early to review emails and plan my schedule for the day. I work a standard Monday through Friday schedule, but I've learned to be flexible when needed, especially when my kids are in town or when there's a family event. I enjoy the challenge of my work because it allows me to combine my passion for people with my interest in organizational systems. It's not always easy—there are days when I feel like I'm juggling a hundred different tasks at once—but I find it rewarding to help create a positive work environment where people can thrive.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Claire Romero: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay balanced. I've always been into reading, and I try to set aside at least an hour each evening to lose myself in a book—whether it's fiction, nonfiction, or something about psychology. I also practice yoga a few times a week, which helps me manage stress and stay grounded. I've been doing it for a few years now, and it's become a kind of ritual for me. There's something about the quiet focus and the physical movement that helps me reset after a busy day. I also make it a point to volunteer a few hours each month at a local community center, mostly with their youth programs. It's not something I do for recognition, but more for the sense of connection it gives me. I think it's important to give back, especially in a place like Newton, where so many people have supported me over the years.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Claire Romero: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I used to just grab my coffee and rush out the door, but I've started taking ten to fifteen minutes to sit quietly, breathe deeply, and set an intention for the day. It's something I began after a particularly stressful project at work, and it's made a noticeable difference in how I approach my tasks and interactions. I also started taking my dog, Max, for a longer walk in the mornings, which has become a kind of ritual for me. It's a time to clear my mind, enjoy the fresh air, and just be present. I think these small changes have helped me feel more centered, especially with everything else going on in my life.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Claire Romero: My children are both adults now, so their routines are a bit different from what they were during the school years, but I remember what it was like for them. During the school year, my son, Marco, would typically wake up early for his morning classes at a local university, and my daughter, Elena, had a similar schedule when she was in high school. Both of them were involved in extracurricular activities—Marco played on the school's soccer team and volunteered at a community center, while Elena was in theater and participated in debate club. After school, they'd often have homework, but they also made time for friends and hobbies. I always encouraged them to find balance, and I think that helped them develop a strong work ethic and a sense of responsibility. Even now, I see those habits in how they approach their careers and personal lives. It's amazing how the lessons from their childhood carry over into adulthood.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my daily life is shaped by the balance between structure and flexibility. Talking about my neighborhood, my job, and my personal routines reminded me of how important it is to have a sense of stability, especially after the changes I've experienced in my personal life. I've come to appreciate the small rituals that keep me grounded—whether it's my morning walk with Max, my evening reading, or my weekly yoga practice. These habits aren't just about routine; they're about taking care of myself and staying connected to what matters most. At the same time, I've learned to be open to change, whether it's adjusting my schedule for my kids or embracing new mindfulness practices. Life is a mix of consistency and adaptability, and I'm grateful for the balance I've found here in Newton.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Claire Romero: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape, though I've had my share of ups and downs over the years. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—I wasn't into sports like soccer or basketball, but I loved walking, hiking, and eventually yoga. I think staying physically active has been a key part of how I've managed stress, especially through my divorce and the challenges that came with it. That said, I've had a few health issues over the years, like chronic back pain from sitting at a desk for long hours, which I've been working on with regular chiropractic visits and physical therapy. I also had a mild case of depression after my divorce, which I addressed through therapy and mindfulness practices. I'm lucky to have a good relationship with my primary care doctor, who has been supportive in helping me manage both my physical and mental health. I try to eat well—mostly whole foods, lean proteins, and plenty of vegetables—and I've cut back on processed foods and sugar over the past few years. I also make sure to get enough sleep, even if it's not always easy with a busy work schedule and family life. Overall, I see health as something that requires attention and care, and I'm committed to maintaining it as best as I can.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Claire Romero: For me, staying healthy is both easy and hard in different ways. On the one hand, I have a strong support system—my family, my friends, and even my coworkers—who encourage me to take care of myself. My routine of walking with Max, practicing yoga, and reading before bed gives me a sense of structure that helps me stay on track. But on the other hand, life can get busy, and there are days when I skip a workout or grab a quick, unhealthy meal because I'm running late or stressed. I think the hardest part is finding the balance between being productive and taking care of myself. Sometimes, I feel guilty for prioritizing my health when there are so many other demands on my time. But I've come to realize that taking care of myself isn't a luxury—it's a necessity. When I make time for my health, it actually makes me more productive and present in every other area of my life. So I try to remind myself that small, consistent choices matter more than perfection.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Claire Romero: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some flare-ups of my chronic back pain, which has been more persistent than usual. I think it's partly due to the long hours I've been spending at my desk, especially with the rise of remote work and hybrid schedules. I've been seeing my chiropractor more frequently and have started incorporating some strengthening exercises into my routine, which has helped a bit. I also had a minor knee injury a few months ago from a misstep while walking on the trail near my house. It wasn't anything serious, but it reminded me how important it is to be mindful of my body, especially as I get older. On the positive side, I've been more consistent with my yoga practice and meditation, which has helped me manage the pain and stress better. I've also started eating more mindfully, focusing on whole foods and staying hydrated, which I think has contributed to feeling more balanced overall. It's been a learning process, but I'm trying to be more proactive about my health now rather than reactive.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Claire Romero: I think the health challenges I've faced over the past few years have definitely had an impact on my daily life, though not in a way that's stopped me from working or being there for my kids. The back pain, for instance, has made some days more difficult, especially when I'm sitting for long periods at work or trying to keep up with my kids when they were younger. But I've learned to manage it with a combination of physical therapy, yoga, and mindfulness. I've also had to be more intentional about pacing myself, especially when I'm juggling work and family responsibilities. There were times when I felt like I was pushing through the pain just to get things done, but I've come to realize that taking a step back and taking care of myself actually helps me be more present for the people I love. I think the key has been finding a balance between pushing through and knowing when to rest. It's not always easy, but I've grown a lot from it, and I'm grateful for the lessons it's taught me about resilience and self-care.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Claire Romero: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I've felt more grounded and at peace with where I am in life, and other days I've felt the weight of everything that's happened. My divorce was a few years ago now, but the adjustments that come with being a single parent and navigating life on my own still have moments that challenge me. I've been working on building a stronger sense of self, not just as a mother or a professional, but as an individual who deserves to be happy and fulfilled. I've also been focusing more on my mental health, which has been a journey in itself. There were times when I felt like I was just going through the motions, but I've made a conscious effort to reconnect with the things that bring me joy—whether it's spending time with my kids, reading a good book, or getting out in nature. I think the past year has been about healing, growth, and learning to embrace the present rather than being stuck in the past. It's not always easy, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself and more patient with the process.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily habits have shaped my overall well-being. Talking about my morning mindfulness practice, my dog walks, and the challenges of staying healthy in a busy life reminded me of how important it is to take small, consistent steps toward self-care. I used to think of health as something that would take up too much time or energy, but now I see it as a foundation that supports everything else—my work, my relationships, and even my ability to cope with life's challenges. It's also made me more aware of how my body and mind are connected, and how something as simple as a morning walk or a few minutes of meditation can make a real difference in how I feel throughout the day. I'm still learning, and there are definitely days when I slip up or feel overwhelmed, but I'm trying to be more intentional about my health now, not just for myself, but for the people I love and the life I want to live.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Claire Romero: I think I've struggled with anxiety at times, especially during the transition after my divorce. There were moments when I felt overwhelmed by the responsibilities of being a single parent, managing my job, and trying to rebuild my life on my own. I remember feeling like I was constantly juggling too many things at once, and there were days when I didn't know where to start. I didn't want to burden anyone with my feelings, so I often kept it all inside. But over time, I realized that asking for help wasn't a weakness—it was a strength. I started seeing a therapist, and that made a world of difference. It gave me a safe space to explore my emotions and work through the things that were holding me back. I also found that mindfulness and yoga helped me stay grounded when my thoughts started spiraling. I don't think I've ever been officially diagnosed with anxiety, but I know I've experienced it in different ways throughout my life. What's important to me now is that I'm more aware of my mental health and more willing to take care of it, even when it's hard.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Claire Romero: For my family, it's been a mix of adjustment and resilience. My children have always been incredibly supportive, even though they were going through their own transitions as young adults. My son, Marco, was just starting his career when I went through the divorce, and he took on a lot more responsibility at home, helping me with things like cooking and managing the household. My daughter, Elena, was away at college, but she stayed in close contact and made sure I knew I wasn't alone. It wasn't easy for any of us, but I think we all grew from it in different ways. My parents, too, have been a steady presence—my mother, in particular, has been a great source of wisdom and comfort. She's someone who's lived through her own share of challenges, and she's always reminded me that life has a way of sorting itself out if you stay strong and keep moving forward. I think the most important thing for my family has been learning how to communicate openly, even when things are hard. It's not perfect, but I feel like we've come out of it with a deeper understanding of each other and a stronger bond.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Claire Romero: For me, religion has always been an important part of my life, though it's evolved over time. I was raised Catholic, and my parents made sure that faith was a central part of our family life. We attended Mass regularly, and I remember the sense of community and comfort that came with being part of that tradition. Even now, I still find value in the rituals and teachings of the Catholic Church, especially during times of reflection or challenge. That said, my spirituality has become more personal in recent years. I don't always attend Mass as often as I used to, but I still find solace in prayer, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed or in need of guidance. I think of my faith as something that's not just about doctrine or tradition, but about connection—whether it's with God, with my family, or with the world around me. It's a source of strength, even if it's not always perfect or easy to understand.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Claire Romero: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I've always been more of a private person, and I find that platforms like Facebook or Instagram can sometimes feel overwhelming or superficial. That said, I do use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with family and old friends, especially since my children are living in different cities. I'll check in on their posts, share a few photos of my dog Max or my garden, and sometimes join in on family events or holidays. I think it's a way to stay connected without feeling like I have to curate my life for others. I also follow a few local community pages for Newton, which keep me informed about events and happenings in the neighborhood. But overall, I prefer face-to-face interactions or even a phone call over scrolling through feeds. I think there's a certain kind of peace in not being constantly connected, and I try to be intentional about how I use technology in my life.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Claire Romero: Honestly, I don't think I've ever relied on social media for emotional or financial support, and I don't think I ever will. I've always found that the people I care about are the ones who show up in real life, not behind a screen. That said, there have been times when I've felt overwhelmed or isolated, and I've reached out to friends or family for support—whether it was a phone call, a message, or just showing up at someone's door. I think the difference is that I've always preferred face-to-face connections, where you can really see someone's face, hear their voice, and feel their presence. Social media can be a tool for staying connected, but it's not a substitute for real relationships. I've seen people get lost in the noise of online interactions, and I've always tried to keep my own life grounded in the people and experiences that matter most to me.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and emotional well-being have shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about my chronic back pain, my minor knee injury, and the ongoing challenges of managing my mental health reminded me of how deeply interconnected my physical and emotional states are. It's easy to overlook the toll that everyday stress and responsibilities can take on the body, but I've come to realize that neglecting my health—whether physical or mental—can have real consequences. I've also been thinking about how my anxiety, especially after my divorce, has been a part of my story, and how important it was for me to seek support through therapy and mindfulness. I used to feel like I had to handle everything on my own, but now I see that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. These reflections have helped me understand that healing is not a linear process—it's about showing up for myself, even on the hardest days, and being patient with the journey.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Claire Romero: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have fluctuated, especially with the added pressures of work and the ongoing adjustments in my personal life. There were times when I felt like I was carrying everything on my own, and that weight was hard to shake. But I've been working on developing better coping strategies. One of the biggest changes has been how I approach mindfulness—rather than just a quick meditation here and there, I've made it a daily practice. I also started journaling, which has been a huge help in processing my thoughts and emotions. It's amazing how writing things down can clarify what's going on inside. I've also leaned more on my support system, whether it's talking to my mother, catching up with Sarah, or even just having a quiet conversation with James at work. I think the key has been learning to recognize when I'm feeling overwhelmed and taking small, intentional steps to care for myself. It's not always easy, but I'm getting better at it, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Claire Romero: Last month, my biggest expenses were related to my mortgage, groceries, and healthcare. I live in a modest home on Chestnut Hill Ave, and the mortgage payment is a consistent part of my budget. Groceries can be a bit of a challenge with my current schedule, but I try to plan meals in advance and buy in bulk when possible. Healthcare costs have also been a significant part of my monthly spending, especially with my ongoing chiropractic visits and the need for regular check-ups. I also set aside money for my car payments, insurance, and a small amount for personal expenses like books or yoga classes. I'm pretty careful with my budget, and I try to track my spending using a simple spreadsheet. It's not always perfect, but I've learned to prioritize what's most important—like my health, my family, and the stability of my home. I also make sure to save a little each month, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's not about luxury, but about being prepared and living within my means.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Claire Romero: Last month, our household spent around $3,200, which is pretty much in line with our usual monthly budget. The majority of that goes toward the mortgage, which is about $1,500, and groceries, which typically run around $800 to $900 depending on the season and what's on sale. Healthcare is another big chunk—my chiropractic visits, prescriptions, and insurance premiums add up to about $600 a month. I also set aside around $400 for car payments and insurance, and another $300 for miscellaneous expenses like utilities, personal care, and the occasional weekend outing with my kids when they're in town. I try to be as careful as I can with my money, and I've gotten pretty good at tracking where it all goes. It's not always easy, especially when unexpected things come up, but I've learned that living within my means doesn't mean sacrificing what matters most—it just means being intentional about how I spend and save.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Claire Romero: We own our home. It's a modest three-bedroom house on Chestnut Hill Ave, and it's been our family's home for over a decade. Buying it was a big decision at the time, but it's been a great investment both financially and emotionally. It's not a huge house, but it's comfortable and has a lot of character—original hardwood floors, a small but cozy backyard, and a porch where I like to sit in the evenings with a cup of tea. Owning a home has given me a sense of stability, especially after the changes in my personal life. I know that it's not just a place to live, but a foundation for the life I've built here in Newton. I've always believed that having a place you can call your own is important, and I'm grateful that we were able to make this house our own.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Claire Romero: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, as they do for most people. For example, during the winter months, my heating bill went up significantly, which is something I wasn't fully prepared for. I had to adjust my budget a bit, cutting back on some discretionary spending to make sure I could cover the increased utility costs. Then, around the holidays, there were unexpected expenses—like a new set of tires for my car, which I needed because the old ones were worn down, and a few small gifts for my kids and parents. On the flip side, I noticed that my grocery bills were a bit lower in the spring because I was able to buy more seasonal produce at local farmers' markets, which not only saved me money but also felt more meaningful. I also had a few months where my healthcare costs were higher due to additional physical therapy sessions, which I needed after a flare-up of my back pain. Overall, I've learned to be more flexible with my budget and to plan ahead for seasonal changes, even if it means making small adjustments along the way.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and my approach to connection have shaped my emotional resilience. Talking about my children's support during my divorce, my parents' steady presence, and how my faith has evolved over time reminded me of the importance of having a strong foundation in both personal relationships and spiritual practice. I've come to realize that healing isn't just about overcoming challenges—it's about leaning on the people who matter most and finding comfort in the traditions and beliefs that have guided me through difficult times. It's also made me think about how I choose to engage with the world, especially in terms of social media. While I don't rely on it for support, I do appreciate the ways it can keep me connected to family and community without feeling like I have to perform or present a version of myself that isn't real. These reflections have helped me understand that true connection comes from authenticity, not from the number of likes or shares I receive online.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Claire Romero: I do have a savings account, and I try to save consistently, even if it's just a small amount each month. I've always believed that having a financial cushion is important, especially after going through my divorce and realizing how quickly life can change. I set aside about $200 a month automatically from my checking account into a high-yield savings account, and I also try to save any extra income I get from side projects or bonuses. I think of it as a way to prepare for the unexpected—whether it's a medical expense, a car repair, or something else that comes up. I'm not a big saver by nature, but I've learned that even small, consistent contributions add up over time. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared and feeling a little more in control of my financial future.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Claire Romero: In the last year, I've been saving more with a focus on both short-term and long-term goals. On the short-term side, I've been building up an emergency fund to cover unexpected expenses, like car repairs or medical bills, which I know can come up without warning. I've also been setting aside money for family trips or special occasions, like holidays or my parents' birthdays, which are important to me. On the long-term side, I've been contributing to a retirement account, even if it's just a small amount each month. I think it's important to start early, even if you're not putting in a lot at first. I've also been saving for a bigger project—maybe a home renovation or a trip I've been dreaming about for a while. It's not about having everything perfect, but about being intentional with my money and making sure I'm working toward something that matters to me.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Claire Romero: I work full time in human resources at a mid-sized tech company, and my role is pretty varied. On a day-to-day basis, I handle a lot of the behind-the-scenes work that keeps the workplace running smoothly—things like employee onboarding, performance reviews, conflict resolution, and making sure our company culture supports everyone. One of the most important parts of my job is fostering a positive and inclusive environment. I've always believed that people thrive when they feel valued and respected, and that's something I try to bring into every interaction. I also work closely with our leadership team on diversity and inclusion initiatives, which is something I'm really passionate about. It's not always easy—there are days when I feel like I'm juggling a hundred different tasks at once—but I find it rewarding to help create a workplace where people can grow, collaborate, and feel supported. It's a job that requires a lot of empathy, communication, and problem-solving, and I think those are the skills that have kept me grounded and successful in this field.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Claire Romero: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the time of year or any special projects we're working on. My job doesn't have a strict nine-to-five schedule, so I often start a little earlier and stay late when needed. I've learned to be flexible with my time, especially since my kids are adults and their schedules don't always align with mine. That said, I do make it a point to leave work at a reasonable hour most days so I can enjoy the rest of my evening—whether it's reading, spending time with my dog, or just sitting on the porch and watching the sunset. I think it's important to have a work-life balance, even if it's not perfect. I've had to learn when to push through and when to step back, and I try to be intentional about how I spend my time both at work and at home.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Claire Romero: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on building a solid career in human resources, and while I've taken on some part-time consulting work in the past—mainly for nonprofit organizations focused on employee well-being—it's never been a full-time commitment. I think having a single, stable job has been important for me, especially after my divorce, when I needed the structure and routine that a consistent work schedule provided. That said, I've always been open to opportunities that align with my values, even if they're on the side. For example, I've volunteered my time to help small businesses with their HR policies, and I've even led a few workshops on workplace mindfulness. It's not about expanding my income, but more about staying engaged with the work I care about and giving back in a way that feels meaningful.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined in my daily life. Talking about my stress levels, my coping strategies, and how I manage my household budget reminded me of the importance of balance—both in how I care for myself and how I manage the responsibilities that come with adulthood. I've come to realize that taking time for mindfulness, journaling, and leaning on my support system isn't just about managing stress; it's about creating a foundation that allows me to be present for the things that matter most. At the same time, being intentional with my finances, whether it's saving for the future or adjusting my budget for seasonal changes, gives me a sense of control that I didn't always have. I've learned that both emotional and financial health require attention, patience, and a willingness to adapt as life continues to change around me.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Claire Romero: In total, my household made around $6,500 in the past month. That comes from my full-time salary at the tech company, which is about $5,000 after taxes, and a small part-time consulting gig I've been doing with a local nonprofit focused on workplace wellness. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover our monthly expenses and allow for a little extra for savings or unexpected costs. I've always believed in living within my means, and I try to be mindful of every dollar I earn. It's not about luxury—it's about stability, security, and being able to provide for the things that matter most, like my health, my family, and the life I've built here in Newton.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Claire Romero: I've been at my current job for about seven years now, and it's been a really rewarding experience. The company has a strong commitment to employee well-being, which is something I really appreciate. In terms of benefits, we have comprehensive health insurance that covers medical, dental, and vision, which is a huge relief, especially with my ongoing chiropractic care and any other health needs that come up. We also get a generous amount of paid time off—around three weeks of vacation, plus sick days and personal days. I think the flexibility of the schedule is one of the best parts. While I do work a standard Monday through Friday schedule, I have the option to start a bit earlier or stay a bit later depending on what's needed. The company also offers a retirement plan with matching contributions, which is something I've been contributing to for years. I've always believed that a job is more than just a paycheck—it's about the support, the stability, and the opportunities to grow. This workplace has given me all of that, and I'm really grateful for it.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Claire Romero: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I've always valued collaboration, and I think that's something that comes through in how I interact with my manager and my coworkers. My manager, Linda, is someone I really respect—she's supportive, fair, and has a great understanding of what it takes to lead a team. She's been a great mentor to me over the years, and I've learned a lot from watching how she handles challenges and leads with empathy. As for my coworkers, I have a good rapport with most of them. We work in different departments, but there's a strong sense of camaraderie, especially when we're working on projects that align with our shared goals of creating a positive workplace culture. I think the key to our relationships is that we all bring different strengths to the table, and we're willing to support each other when needed. There are, of course, the usual office dynamics—some people are more competitive, others more laid-back—but I've found that focusing on common goals and mutual respect helps keep things running smoothly. I wouldn't say I'm the most outgoing person, but I do enjoy the connections I've built over the years, and I feel like I'm part of a team that genuinely cares about each other's success.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Claire Romero: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but I do have some flexibility, which I really appreciate. I typically start around 8:30 a.m. and finish around 5:30 p.m., though I often stay a bit later when there are meetings or projects that need attention. The company has a flexible policy that allows me to adjust my hours a bit, as long as I'm available for core team meetings and client interactions. That said, I do have to be at the office most days, especially when we're working on big initiatives or during busy seasons. I think the predictability of the schedule helps me balance my work and personal life, especially since my kids are adults and their schedules don't always align with mine. It's not perfect, but I've learned to make the most of the structure while still leaving room for spontaneity when needed.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Claire Romero: Overall, I feel pretty stable about my financial situation. It's not extravagant, but it's enough to cover my needs and give me a sense of security. I've learned over the years that it's not about having more, but about being mindful of what I have and making sure I'm not living paycheck to paycheck. I've had my share of financial challenges, especially after my divorce, but I've always tried to stay proactive—whether it's budgeting carefully, saving a little each month, or being intentional about my spending. I also appreciate the benefits that come with my job, like health insurance and retirement contributions, which give me peace of mind. I know there are days when I worry about the future, but I try to focus on what I can control and be grateful for the stability I have. It's not perfect, but I feel like I'm on the right path, and that's something I can be proud of.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial stability and emotional well-being are intertwined in my daily life. Talking about how my bills fluctuate with the seasons, my efforts to save consistently, and the structure of my work schedule reminded me of the importance of balance—both in managing my money and in taking care of myself. I've come to realize that being mindful of my expenses, whether it's adjusting for higher heating costs in the winter or saving for unexpected repairs, is just as important as the emotional coping strategies I've developed over the years. It's comforting to know that I have a stable income and a predictable work schedule, which gives me the freedom to focus on what truly matters—my health, my family, and the life I've built here in Newton. I've learned that financial health isn't about having everything perfect, but about being intentional with what I have and making choices that support both my present and my future.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Claire Romero: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My father was a teacher, and he worked full time at a local high school in our town. He had a stable schedule, which gave me a sense of routine and security from an early age. My mother worked as a nurse, and while her hours were a bit more unpredictable due to shifts at the hospital, she always made sure to be there for our family when it mattered most. I remember her coming home tired but always making time for us—whether it was helping with homework, cooking dinner, or just sitting down for a conversation. Their work wasn't just about providing for us financially; it was about showing me the value of dedication, responsibility, and caring for others. I think those lessons from watching them work have shaped a lot of who I am today, especially in my career in human resources, where I get to support people in their own journeys.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Claire Romero: My father was a high school teacher, and his most important activities revolved around preparing lesson plans, teaching a variety of subjects, and mentoring his students. He had a deep passion for education and always believed that every student had the potential to succeed if given the right support. He often stayed late after school to help students who were struggling or to plan engaging activities for the classroom. My mother was a nurse at a local hospital, and her most important duties involved caring for patients, administering treatments, and providing emotional support during difficult times. She was known for her compassion and dedication, and she often went above and beyond to make sure her patients felt heard and comforted. Both of their jobs required a lot of responsibility and empathy, and I think those qualities are what shaped my own values and career path. Watching them work taught me the importance of service, patience, and the impact one person can have on the lives of others.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Claire Romero: My father worked for the Newton Public Schools, which is a local government entity that oversees all the schools in our town. He taught a mix of subjects, including English and social studies, and he was known for making his classes engaging and thought-provoking. He didn't just stick to the textbook—he encouraged critical thinking and often brought in guest speakers or organized field trips to help students connect what they were learning to the real world. My mother worked at Newton Medical Center, which is a hospital that serves the surrounding communities. She was a registered nurse, and her days were filled with caring for patients, administering medications, and collaborating with doctors and other healthcare professionals. I remember her talking about the challenges of the job, like long hours and emotional stress, but she always emphasized the importance of her work in people's lives. Both of them made sacrifices to provide for our family, and I think that's something I carry with me today—knowing that hard work and dedication can make a real difference, even in the most demanding of jobs.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Claire Romero: I hope that in a few years, I'm still living in Newton, surrounded by the same sense of community and stability that has been such a constant in my life. I hope my work in human resources continues to bring me fulfillment, and that I'm still making a positive impact on the people I work with. I also hope my relationship with my children continues to grow stronger, even as they build their own lives in different cities. I'd love to see them settled, happy, and maybe even with families of their own. On a personal level, I hope I'm still taking care of myself—keeping up with my yoga, staying mindful, and continuing to prioritize my health. I also hope I'm still volunteering in some capacity, whether it's with the community center or another cause that matters to me. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I do know that I want to stay grounded, connected, and true to the values that have guided me through everything I've been through.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Claire Romero: What I value the most in my life is connection—whether it's with my family, my friends, or the people I work with. I think relationships are what give life its meaning, and I'm so grateful for the ones I have. I also value stability, not in the sense of never changing, but in having a foundation that I can rely on, like my home in Newton, my job, and the routines that help me feel grounded. I value growth, too—both personal and professional. I believe that life is about learning, adapting, and becoming the best version of yourself, even when it's hard. And finally, I value authenticity. I think it's important to be true to who you are, even when the world tries to push you in a different direction. I've learned that the most meaningful parts of life come from being present, from showing up for the people you love, and from staying true to your values, even when things get complicated.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my financial stability and work environment contribute to my overall sense of well-being. Talking about my monthly income, my savings habits, and the benefits of my job reminded me of how important it is to have a balance between earning, saving, and living within my means. It also made me appreciate the structure and support that my workplace provides—especially the flexibility, health benefits, and the positive relationships I've built with my manager and coworkers. I've come to realize that having a stable job isn't just about the paycheck; it's about feeling valued, supported, and empowered to grow both professionally and personally. It's comforting to know that I have a foundation in place that allows me to focus on what truly matters—my health, my family, and the life I've built here in Newton.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and rediscovery. It's amazing how much of my life has been shaped by the people I've loved, the choices I've made, and the experiences that have tested and strengthened me. From my childhood in Newton, where my parents instilled in me the values of education and hard work, to the pivotal internship that set me on the path to human resources, each step has led me to where I am today. I've learned that life isn't just about the big moments—it's about the small, consistent choices we make every day, whether it's showing up for our family, taking care of our health, or staying true to our values. I'm grateful for the support of my advisor, my mother, my friends, and my coworkers, who have all played a role in shaping who I am. Even though my life has had its share of challenges, I've come to see them not as obstacles, but as opportunities for growth. This interview has reminded me of how much I've grown over the years, and how much I still have to look forward to. I'm proud of the life I've built, and I'm excited to see what the future holds.
